clues.text: The Gulf Stream runs close to Cuba & in this Hemingway novel Santiago fishes in it
In a Graham Greene novel, James Wormold is recruited by British Secret Service to be "Our Man in" this city
Reinaldo Arenas' memoir "Before Night Falls" recounts his attempts to flee Communist Cuba, even swimming to this U.S. naval station
Oscar Hijuelos wrote a novel about the title "Kings" of this Cuban ballroom dance
Joe falls for a Cuban revolutionary in "Live by Night" by this "Shutter Island" author, who normally does Massachusetts
Anatomical term for the place where a river empties into the sea
It can be a line of mountain ridges or a grazing land for animals
A Montana city nicknamed "The Richest Hill on Earth" or a term for an isolated hill
Though far from the Sahara, the lakeshore at the national park called Indiana these features has some 200-footers
1 million people in Los Angeles County live in this type of area, part of no municipality
Stephen King novel in which Chester's Mill, Maine is sealed off from the rest of the world
Anthony Kiedis wrote this song about the loneliness of heroin addiction
Prince's acting oeuvre includes "Purple Rain", "Graffiti Bridge" & this 1986 film
A writer impulsively buys an Italian villa in this book, later a Diane Lane film
Malcolm Lowry's Mexico-set masterpiece
Phineas Quimby, who influenced Mary Baker Eddy, is best known for his theory that this type of problem is all in the mind
Jonathan Edwards thought sin was restrained by God; otherwise the soul would be "a furnace of" these two things
Philosopher Martha Nussbaum is a neo-this ancient Greek stiff-upper-lip type, but Martha allows for more emotion
William James popularized this -ism that judges ideas by their usefulness, now a synonym for "practicality"
Instead of Christmas the family in the movie "Captain Fantastic" observes the birthday of this linguist & left-wing social critic
A stranded German motorist might say "Mein auto ist" this, a word we use in English for anything busted
A form of self-defense primarily without weapons, karate is Japanese for "empty" these
A cappella means "in the style of the chapel" in Italian, but it means this to us
Literally French for "blow of mercy", it's any finishing stroke, especially to end suffering
From Yiddish, for "juicy", this end-of-the-alphabet word means pleasingly plump or buxom
In a 1931 cartoon this Disney dog said, "Kiss me!" but has been a canine of very, very few words since
In addition to 3 Musketeers bars, this corporation also owns brands like Uncle Ben's & Whiskas
A song by Train begins, "Now that she's back in the atmosphere, with drops of" this "in her hair"
Part of the name of a Canadian province, it's a type of lox
In Greek mythology this daughter of Cassiopeia was chained to a rock as a sacrifice

rounds.comments: (Alex: We're gonna deal with all four verses.)

clues.text: They provide a "red glare" to the battle scene
Verse 4 says, "Then conquer we must, when our cause it is just, And this be our motto--'In God is our'" this
The "towering steep" in verse 2 is this edifice that was under attack by the British
In a kids' book this phrase leads Ramona Quimby to think a lamp is called a dawnzer
This phrase about liberty in all 4 verses provides the title of a song by The Killers where it has a more ironic meaning
On rooftops grotesque statues aren't gargoyles unless they serve as one of these for rain
The singing gargoyles in this 1996 Disney cartoon are named Victor, Hugo & Laverne
Some of the earliest known gargoyles are these animals on the Temple of Zeus; maybe they're the Nemean type
Paisley Abbey in Scotland added a new gargoyle likely inspired by this 1979 horror film
The gargoyles on this Manhattan building named for an auto executive are less earthbound--they're eagles
By Bret Easton Ellis: "Less Than ____"
"The ____ Habits of Highly Effective People"
An international bestseller: "The ____ -Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared"
From "The Charge of the Light Brigade": "All in the valley of Death rode the ___"
A Temperance Brennan novel: "___ Bones" (referring to the number of bones in the body)
This South American country has about 4,600 miles of Atlantic coastline
Cities along this U.S. state's ocean coast include Astoria & Brookings
This nation's 2,100-mile coastline extends from the Gulf of Thailand to the Gulf of Tonkin
This nation takes its name from the Latin Mare Erythraeum, meaning "Red Sea", the body of water the nation borders
It's the only Central American country without a coastline on the Pacific Ocean
Indium is named for this deep blue color
Palladium honors one of these space objects that's named for Pallas Athena
Swedish chemist Jöns Jacob Berzelius named this element for a thunder god
This noble gas is named for an element discovered by the Curies
Symbol Ga, this element is named from the Latin for France & maybe also the Latin for rooster (it was named by M. Lecoq)

rounds.comments: (Alex: ...each correct response will begin with the letters "T-E-N".)

clues.text: An apartment dweller
In the U.S., it's the most popular form of bowling
It's an adjective meaning pertaining to the most popular British poet of the Victorian era
In a state of anxiety? You're "on" these 11-letter items
The khayyam in Omar Khayyam means this profession

rounds.text: Per Guinness, this character who debuted in 1887 is the most portrayed human literary character in film & television
